topic.title: Google's ML fairness, atomisation and civil war.
topic.body:
Google uses an algorithm in their searches affecting all the engines like YouTube, web search and the way it recommends content.

It is called machine learned fairness, but it is far from a naturally learned system. Google has biased the system with intersectional social justices, for example the algorithms will bring up minorities in an image search for white family or fire fighter will show you equal amounts of men and women regardless of reality.

The purpose is unclear but social engineering comes to mind, infact you can probably draw parallels to the Cambridge analytica scandal where it is clear weapons grade social engineering was used on the public to engineer election outcomes.

The part that eludes me is the end result doesn't seem to reflect the assumed outcome, if the intention is to engineer leftist social ideaology then why strike a divide pushing both left and right extremism? One strange thing I have witnessed is searching Family shows you mostly accurate results that represents the country you are in but searching white family shows mostly minorities, another example is Facebook has purposely designed allot of its functionality around atomisation of groups and mostly just like twitter banned the milk toast people while leaving the extreme personalities on the platforms.

The endgame cannot end well. They are engineering a civil war, it's the only logical conclusion.

topic.title: Ukrain Airlines plane likely shot down by TOR M1 Missile
topic.body:
Iraq and US sources are leaning to this explanation.

Basically Iran anti air system was on a hair trigger scared of US counter attack after attacking 2 US airbases and someone jumped the gun and shot the plane down.

4 possibilities exist.
Passenger explosive on board
UAV crash into the plane
mechanical failure

internal attack, Iran uses TOR M1 missiles, this seems to be the most likely. parts of one of these missiles was found on the ground. The planes transponder died at the beginning of the plane exploding on fire, with both engines failed.

Update-

These missiles explode near to target not on impact and spray shrapnel, shrapnel marks on the planes fuselage seem to indicate the missile attack.

topic.title: How they use graphs or plots to lie to you
topic.body:
Often they use a graph or a plot to show you how over the last few decades the planet is getting hotter and hotter to convince you that climate change is a crisis.

Look at this graph ....

http://127.0.0.1:43110/12MVkvYGcRW6u2NYbpfwVad1oQeyG4s9Er/index.html?view:item+id:15f2_12BRJSQrTETJVZzt2jHdqPywv3SdugSywC_item_2392+type:image

# the trick is framing

How you frame your data is the lie, don't be dishonest show the entire data or don't show anything at all, if you only show the last bit yes all you see is the planet getting hotter since the industrial age but the reality is that the world is much cooler today then much of the past.

Sounds like a splendid well managed project filled with lovely people
the boot strapper is the main thing you should enable under plugins, it helps your client provide tracking n stuff.

A torrent tracker takes announcement from peers when they want to find something from other peers. The tracker responds with a list of seeds that seeders told the tracker they are seeding.

When you enable the boot strapper you are not a listed tracker but peers that connect to each other pass on trackers through peer exchange and will include you as one of those trackers. You kind of become an unofficial tracker to help maintain a list of peers. 

Generally you will mostly only providing a list of peers for the things you are seeding since you're only included via peer exchange and thus only peers that are around you become aware of your tracker.

Most people only run zeronet use it then close it and don't leave the background zeronet service running. In this case it would do more harm than good to have you telling other peers you would provide tracking because you will be timing out when you're gone.

The default setting caters to majority use case.

It really depends on what in particular has scaled.

I have no problems with big sites but one issue in particular is millchan after going over approx 25,000 optional files.
Further file seed requests cause very high cpu usage with lengthy UI slow downs and if I end up with over around 2000 new files that need to be updated In the queue it can cause zeronet to become completely unresponsive for several minutes.
Also the amount of memory zeronet is using slowly grows from the usual 200 to 400Mb to 4 to 6Gb, At  this point I'm up to >36000 files now I can't click seed files for boards anymore I have to click seed all on individual thread posts and keep the queue below 500 to avoid zeronet having a meltdown.

General advice about Tor

1. Traffic is been encrypted and this has to be done in realtime to minimise latency.
2. CPU encryption extension's will drastically improve performance for Tor and VPN alike. You can use CPUz to check your CPU features.
3. Tor runs over TCP and this has many performance drawbacks.

A. TCP requires packets be responded to with acknowledgement packets before more packets are sent. This causes a 2x latency increase that stacks over time depending on the size and length of the data been transferred.
B. TCP connections running over TCP tunnels can and often do suffer from acknowledgement of acknowledgement effects. The connection in the tunnel sends an acknowledgement reply and the tunnel itself has to send an acknowledgement of the packet that carried the acknowledgement inside the tunnel ü§îü§î maybe it would be easier to understand temporal theory of time travel.

4. The more individual number of connections increases the number of packets per second so you would see more speed performing a single large file download vs running a torrent downloading pieces from many peers. This is due to an increase in acknowledgement packets and protocol overhead.

5. TCP tunnels use allot more upload, this is due to the TCP protocol overheads compared to UDP and the acknowledgement packets. Also VPN tunnels carry encryption overhead and so tiny TCP protocol packets will all carry the encryption baggage.

As an example, an average UDP OpenVPN tunnel using high levels of encryption will use around 1mbit of upload for every 10mbit of download. TCP usually triples this. 2x for the TCP tunnel and 1x more for TCP over TCP effects.

IPFS is a series of planetside interconnected nodes that provide backhaul capacity between our planets within solar systems, they carry internet, telecoms etc.
